title: AB 332
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Recent public opinion research in California shows that residents, regardless of political party or income level, are concerned about the costs of aging. Two-thirds of respondents worry about affording long-term care, with 63% expressing equal concern for long-term care costs as for future healthcare expenses. A majority cannot afford more than three months of nursing home care at an average cost of $6,000 per month, and 40% cannot afford even a single month. Among Latino voters, 88% lack long-term care insurance or are unsure about coverage for services like in-home care, highlighting widespread financial worries across income levels and political affiliations. The Legislature intends to establish a task force to explore creating a culturally competent statewide insurance program for long-term care services. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will be created in the Department of Insurance to design and implement the program, consisting of nine members including the commissioner and representatives from health care and aging departments appointed by the Governor. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will consist of nine members, including the commissioner as chair, representatives from health care and aging departments, and appointees with expertise in long-term care insurance, health policy, long-term care providers, senior/consumer organizations, and long-term care workers. Members will not receive compensation for their service. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will have members appointed by the Speaker of the Assembly and the Senate Committee on Rules, including representatives from employee organizations and the long-term care insurance industry. Task force members will not receive compensation for their service and meetings will be governed by the Bagley-Keene Open Meeting Act. The task force will explore the design and implementation of a statewide long-term care insurance program to provide options for individuals needing long-term care services. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will explore the design of a statewide long-term care insurance program, including eligibility, benefits, financing, and interaction with Medi-Cal. Consideration will be given to integrating the program into the state disability insurance structure. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force is considering integrating a long-term care insurance program into the state disability insurance structure. This program would allow working adults to enroll and make voluntary premium contributions, with a possible nominal increase in payroll tax. Mandatory enrollment with a voluntary opt-out option may be required, providing basic insurance benefits for those with functional or cognitive limitations to access nonmedical services and supports. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force is considering a program to help individuals with limitations stay in their communities by purchasing nonmedical services. It aims to offset costs for adults with chronic conditions and evaluate coordination with private health care coverage. The program also considers the long-term care workforce demands and the establishment of a joint public-private system for accessibility in California. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force is evaluating the demands on the long-term care workforce in California and considering the establishment of a joint public and private system to make long-term care accessible. Recommendations will be made regarding regulatory provisions for accessing existing and future long-term care insurance programs. The department and governmental agencies involved will operate within their existing budgetary resources. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will recommend options for a statewide long-term care insurance program in a report to be submitted by July 1, 2017. Participating agencies must operate within their existing budgets. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will recommend options for a statewide long-term care insurance program in a report to be submitted by July 1, 2017. The department will produce an actuarial report by July 1, 2018, based on the task force's recommendations. The commissioner may seek private funds for implementation. The commissioner may seek private funds for implementing this section, which will be in effect until January 1, 2019, unless extended by a later statute enacted before that date.
